etymology.description: 江(river) + 湖(lake) = “rivers and lakes” → the world outside officialdom; martial world.
etymology.interpretation: Literally “rivers and lakes”; in classical usage, a metonym for places and people outside the imperial court and bureaucracy. In wuxia culture, refers to the self-governed social sphere of martial artists with its own codes, alliances, and rivalries.

parts.english: lake; lagoon; Hunan (abbr.); body of water

examples.chinese: 他在江湖闯荡多年(他在江湖闖蕩多年)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài jiānghú chuǎngdàng duō nián.
examples.english: He has roamed the martial world for many years.

examples.chinese: 在官场之外的江湖(在官場之外的江湖)，规矩同样严格(規矩同樣嚴格)。
examples.pinyin: Zài guānchǎng zhī wài de jiānghú, guījǔ tóngyàng yán gé.
examples.english: Outside the bureaucracy, the jianghu has strict rules too.

examples.chinese: 他虽不问江湖(他雖不問江湖)，却常听人谈论武林轶事(卻常聽人談論武林軼事)。
examples.pinyin: Tā suī bù wèn jiānghú, què cháng tīng rén tánlùn wǔlín yìshì.
examples.english: Although he keeps out of the jianghu, he often hears people talk about martial tales.
